bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 167, Number 115 (Thursday, July 1, 2021)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. AUSTIN SCOTT of Georgia:H.R. 4337.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8 of the U.S. Constitution[Page H3602]

item.name: Commodity Exchanges, Energy, and Credit Subcommittee
Commodity Exchanges, Energy, and Credit Subcommittee

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Commodity Exchanges, Energy, and Credit.
Referred to the House Committee on Agriculture.

summary.text:
Commodity Futures Trading Commission Research and Development Modernization Act

This bill directs the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to establish and maintain research, development, demonstration, and information programs regarding emerging technologies and their application to commodities markets. The commission may establish research and development plans for such programs. The bill provides requirements for transactions and nonmonetary contributions related to such programs.

bill.title: Commodity Futures Trading Commission Research and Development Modernization Act

item.title: Commodity Futures Trading Commission Research and Development Modernization Act
Commodity Futures Trading Commission Research and Development Modernization Act
To modernize the authority of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to conduct research, development, demonstration, and information programs.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Commodity Exchanges, Energy, and Credit.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
